tit.cmt: 統一リストより、Inarizuka-kofun Tumulusとしました。

sen.j: 稲荷塚古墳（いなりづかこふん）は、東京都多摩市百草にある、古墳時代後期(7世紀前半)の古墳。
sen.e: The Inarizuka Kofun, located in Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture, is a burial mound built in the late Kofun period (the period of ancient burial mounds) (the first half of the 7th century).
The Inarizuka Kofun, located in Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture, is a burial mound built in the late Kofun period (the period of ancient burial mounds) (the first half of the 7th century).

The Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus, located in Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture, is a burial mound built in the late Kofun period (the period of ancient burial mounds) (the first half of the seventh century).
sen.cmt: 統一リストより、Inarizuka-kofun Tumulusとし、7th→seventhとしました。

sen.j: 東京都指定文化財(史跡)に指定されている。
sen.e: It has been designated as an important cultural (historical) property of Tokyo.
It has been designated as an important cultural (historical) property of Tokyo.
It has been designated as an important cultural (historical) property of Tokyo.

sen.j: 江戸時代、稲荷塚古墳の東側に資福院という寺院があったが、明治初年に神仏分離令などの廃仏毀釈により墳丘上に恋路稲荷神社が建てられた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, there was a temple called Shifukuin on the east side of the Inarizuka Kofun; however, due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) such as the Shinbutsu-bunri-rei (a law to forbidden the fusion of Shinto and Buddhism) in the early years of the Meiji period, Koiji-inari shrine was built on the hilltop.

In the Edo period, there was a temple called Shifukuin on the east side of the Inarizuka Kofun; however, due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) such as the Shinbutsu-bunri-rei (a law to forbidden the fusion of Shinto and Buddhism) in the early years of the Meiji period, Koiji-inari shrine was built on the hilltop.

In the Edo period, there was a temple called Shifuku-in on the east side of the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus; however, due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism) such as the Shinbutsu-bunri-rei (a law to forbidden the fusion of Shinto and Buddhism) in the early years of the Meiji period, Koiji-inari Shrine was built on the hilltop.
sen.cmt: Shifuku-in、Inarizuka-kofun Tumulusとし、shrineの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: その際に古墳上部が著しく削平され天井石もほとんど取り去られ周囲はかなり変形した。
sen.e: When the shrine was built, the topsoil of the burial mound was scraped away to level the mound and most of the stones used for the ceiling were also removed, which caused the changes in the circumstances.
When the shrine was built, the topsoil of the burial mound was scraped away to level the mound and most of the stones used for the ceiling were also removed, which caused changes in the circumfrence.
When the shrine was built, the topsoil of the burial mound was scraped away to level the mound and most of the stones used for the ceiling were also removed, which caused changes in the circumfrence.

sen.j: 石室も盗掘され、遺物なども持ち去られたと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that Ishimuro (a stone chamber) was disturbed by grave robbers and the burial items were stolen.
It is said that Ishimuro (a stone chamber) was disturbed by grave robbers and the burial items were stolen.
It is said that the stone chamber was disturbed by grave robbers and the burial items were stolen.
sen.cmt: Ishimuro (a stone chamber)→the stone chamberとしました。

sen.j: 昭和27年(1952年)11月に多摩中学校の教諭が中心となり東京国立博物館の技官と共に多摩中学校の生徒も参加し発掘調査が行われた。
sen.e: In November 1952, an archaeological research was conducted, initiated by the teachers at Tama Junior High School with the help of the engineering officials of the Tokyo National Museum and the students of Tama Junior High School.

In November 1952, an archaeological excavation was conducted, initiated by the teachers at Tama Junior High School with the help of the engineering officials of the Tokyo National Museum and the students of Tama Junior High School.

In November 1952, an archaeological excavation was conducted, initiated by the teachers at Tama Junior High School with the help of the engineering officials of the Tokyo National Museum and the students of Tama Junior High School.

sen.j: 当時、石室の天井石は露出していたが、墳丘、石室が残っている事や石室が胴張複室構造である事が判明したため、翌年(1953年)、東京都指定文化財となった。
sen.e: Next year (1953), it was designated as an important cultural property of Tokyo because although the stones used for the ceiling of the stone chamber were exposed at the time, the burial mound and the stone chamber were remained and it was proved that the stone chamber has a structure called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (Multiple rooms with a womb-like structure).
sen.cmt: 読み方＆定訳不明→「胴張複室構造」
sen.e: The following year (1953), it was designated as an important cultural property of Tokyo because although the stones used for the ceiling of the stone chamber were exposed at the time, the burial mound and the stone chamber remained and it was proved that the stone chamber has a structure called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (multiple rooms with a womb-like structure).

The following year (1953), it was designated as an important cultural property of Tokyo because although the stones used for the ceiling of the stone chamber were exposed at the time, the burial mound and the stone chamber remained and it was proved that the stone chamber has a structure called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (multiple rooms with a womb-like structure).

sen.j: 当初、稲荷塚古墳の形は円墳とされていた。
sen.e: At the beginning, it was considered that the shape of the Inarizuka Kofun was round.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the beginning, it was considered that the shape of the Inarizuka Kofun was round.
At the beginning, it was considered that the shape of the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus was round.

sen.j: しかし1980年代から1990年代前期に調査が行われた結果、東日本では発見の無かった八角墳という事が判明した。
sen.e: However, through the research conducted from the 1980's to the early 1990's, it was proved that it was an octagonal burial mound which had never been discovered in the Eastern Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, through the research conducted from the 1980's to the early 1990's, it was proved that it was an octagonal burial mound which had never been discovered in Eastern Japan.
However, through the research conducted from the 1980's to the early 1990's, it was proved that it was an octagonal burial mound which had never been discovered in Eastern Japan.

sen.j: 築造時期は7世紀前半(古墳時代後期)と推測されている。
sen.e: It is estimated that it was constructed in the first half of the seventh century (the late Kofun period).
It is estimated that it was constructed in the first half of the seventh century (the late Kofun period).
It is estimated that it was constructed in the first half of the seventh century (the late Kofun period).

sen.j: 石室は既に盗掘されていたため被葬者は不明である。
sen.e: Because the stone chamber was already disturbed by grave robbers, it is not known who was buried there.
Because the stone chamber was already disturbed by grave robbers, it is not known who was buried there.
Because the stone chamber was already disturbed by grave robbers, it is not known who was buried there.

sen.j: 以前、石室は公開されていたが、現在は石室の保護のため埋め戻されている。
sen.e: Although the stone chamber used to be open to the public, it is currently backfilled to protect the chamber.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although the stone chamber used to be open to the public, it is currently backfilled to protect the chamber.
Although the stone chamber used to be open to the public, it is currently backfilled to protect the chamber.

sen.j: 色違いのブロックなどで石室の位置や形、大きさが分かるようにしてある。
sen.e: The blocks of different colors are put on the topsoil so that the location, the shape, and the size of the chamber can be recognized.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Blocks of different colors are put on the topsoil so that the location, the shape, and the size of the chamber can be recognized.
Blocks of different colors are put on the topsoil so that the location, the shape, and the size of the chamber can be recognized.

sen.j: 都内の7世紀代の古墳としては八王子市にある北大谷古墳に次ぐ大きさである。
sen.e: Among the seventh-century burial mounds found in Tokyo, it is the next largest burial mound after the Kitaoya Kofun located in Hachioji City.
Among the seventh-century burial mounds found in Tokyo, it is the next largest burial mound after the Kitaoya Kofun located in Hachioji City.
Among the seventh-century burial mounds found in Tokyo, it is the next largest burial mound after the Kitaoya-kofun Tumulus located in Hachioji City.

sen.j: 北大谷古墳は稲荷塚古墳周辺の古墳群とは距離が離れており関連性は不明ではある。
sen.e: It is not clear about the relationship between the Kitaoya Kofun and the group of tombs located around the Inarizuka Kofun burial mound because there is a distance between them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The relationship between the Kitaoya Kofun and the group of tombs located around the Inarizuka Kofun burial mound is not clear because there is some distance between them.
The relationship between the Kitaoya-kofun Tumulus and the group of tombs located around the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus is not clear because there is some distance between them.

sen.j: しかし、石室の構造や築造時期など共通点が多い。
sen.e: However, they have many things in common, such as the structure of the stone chamber and the age of construction.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, they have many things in common, such as the structure of the stone chamber and the age of construction.
However, they have many things in common, such as the structure of the stone chamber and the age of construction.

sen.j: 多摩センター駅にあるパルテノン多摩の歴史ミュージアムではパネルでの稲荷塚古墳の紹介以外に、稲荷塚古墳の石室の復元模型や切り取った石室の床の一部などを展示している。
sen.e: In a history museum in Parthenon Tama located near Tama center station, a model stone chamber of the Inarizuka Kofun and a part of the floor taken from the stone chamber, etc are displayed, in addition to the panels that introduce the Inarizuka Kofun.

In a history museum in Parthenon Tama located near Tama center station, a model stone chamber of the Inarizuka Kofun and a part of the floor taken from the stone chamber, etc are displayed, in addition to the panels that introduce the Inarizuka Kofun.

In a history museum in Parthenon Tama located near Tama-center Station, a model stone chamber of the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus and a part of the floor taken from the stone chamber, etc are displayed, in addition to the panels that introduce the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus.

sen.j: 稲荷塚古墳の全長は38mで周囲には幅2mの周溝がある。
sen.e: The Inarizuka Kofun whose entire length is 38 meters is surrounded by a ditch of two meters width.
The Inarizuka Kofun, whose entire length is 38 meters, is surrounded by a ditch of two meters in width.
The Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus, whose entire length is 38 meters, is surrounded by a ditch of two meters in width.

sen.j: 墳丘の全長は34mで2段構造になっている。
sen.e: The full length of the burial mound is 34 meters and it has a two-tier structure.
The full length of the burial mound is 34 meters and it has a two-tier structure.
The full length of the burial mound is 34 meters and it has a two-tier structure.

sen.j: 高さは4mほどあったと思われるが、恋路稲荷神社を建てる際に2段目が削られ、現在は半分ほどになっている。
sen.e: It is thought that the height was approximately 4 meters; however, the height is reduced by about half because the the top part of the mound was scraped away to construct Koiji-inari shrine.
It is thought that the height was approximately 4 meters; however, the height is reduced by about half because the the top part of the mound was scraped away to construct Koiji-inari shrine.
It is thought that the height was approximately four meters; however, the height is reduced by about half because the the top part of the mound was scraped away to construct Koiji-inari Shrine.
sen.cmt: four metersとし、shrineの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 石室の全長は約7.7mである。
sen.e: Total length of the stone chamber is about 7.7 meters.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Total length of the stone chamber is about 7.7 meters.
Total length of the stone chamber is about 7.7 meters.

sen.j: 羨道部（長さ約1.6m、幅1.2m）・前室（長さ約2.3m、幅1.7m）・玄室（長さ約3.8m、幅3m）の三室からなっている横穴式石室である。
sen.e: It is Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu (a stone chamber with a laterally attached entrance corridor) with three rooms: Sendo-bu (a passageway leading to the "zenshitsu") (about 1.6 meters in length and 1.2 meters in width), zenshitsu (a small room adjoining the "genshitsu") (about 2.3 meters in length and 1.7 meters in width), and genshitsu (a room where coffins and the dead were laid) (about 3.8 meters in length and 3 meters in width).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu (a stone chamber with a laterally attached entrance corridor) with three rooms: Sendo-bu (a passageway leading to the "zenshitsu") (about 1.6 meters in length and 1.2 meters in width), zenshitsu (a small room adjoining the "genshitsu") (about 2.3 meters in length and 1.7 meters in width), and genshitsu (a room where coffins and the dead were laid) (about 3.8 meters in length and 3 meters in width).

It is Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu (a stone chamber with a laterally attached entrance corridor) with three rooms: Sendo-bu (a passageway leading to the "zenshitsu") (about 1.6 meters in length and 1.2 meters in width), zenshitsu (a small room adjoining the "genshitsu") (about 2.3 meters in length and 1.7 meters in width), and genshitsu (a room where coffins and the dead were laid) (about 3.8 meters in length and 3 meters in width).

sen.j: 石室は凝灰岩の切石を組み合わせて積み上げられた構造。
sen.e: The stone chamber was constructed by pilling up the cut tuff stones.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The stone chamber was constructed by pilling up the cut tuff stones.
The stone chamber was constructed by pilling up the cut tuff stones.

sen.j: 玄室の奥壁には高さ1.6m、幅1.2mの一枚石が使用されている。
sen.e: A monolithic stone, 1.6 meters in height and 1.2 meters in width, is used as the back wall of the genshitsu room.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A monolithic stone, 1.6 meters in height and 1.2 meters in width, is used as the back wall of the genshitsu room.
A monolithic stone, 1.6 meters in height and 1.2 meters in width, is used as the back wall of the genshitsu room.

sen.j: 玄室と前室の間には高さ1.7mの門柱石など巨大な石が使用されている。
sen.e: Between the genshitsu and the zenshitsu rooms, enormous stones, such as a stone gate post of 1.70 meters tall is used.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Between the genshitsu and the zenshitsu rooms, enormous stones, such as a stone gate post of 1.70 meters tall, are used.
Between the genshitsu and the zenshitsu rooms, enormous stones, such as a stone gate post of 1.7 meters tall, are used.

sen.j: 前室と玄室の壁は三味線の胴のようにカーブしている。
sen.e: The walls of zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms are curved like the body of a samisen (a three-stringed instrument).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The walls of zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms are curved like the body of a samisen (a three-stringed instrument).
The walls of zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms are curved like the body of a samisen (a three-stringed instrument).

sen.j: 胴張複室構造(子宮の様な形）と呼ばれ精巧な技術で造られている。
sen.e: The structure of the wall is called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (Multiple rooms with a womb-like structure) and it was constructed using the elaborate construction technique.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処読み方＆定訳不明→「胴張複室構造」
sen.e: The structure of the wall is called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (Multiple rooms with a womb-like structure) and it was constructed using an elaborate construction technique.
The structure of the wall is called Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo and it was constructed using an elaborate construction technique.

sen.j: 古墳の構造から朝鮮からの渡来人によって築造されたと推定されている。
sen.e: Judging from the structure of the burial mound, it is estimated that it was constructed by the Koreans who settled in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Judging from the structure of the burial mound, it is estimated that it was constructed by the Koreans who settled in Japan.
Judging from the structure of the burial mound, it is estimated that it was constructed by the Koreans who settled in Japan.

sen.j: 石室の床にはベンガラ（酸化鉄）と呼ばれる赤色の粉が撒かれており、その上に円礫と呼ばれる握りこぶし程の石が敷石として散りばめてある。
sen.e: On the floor of the stone chamber, red powders called Bengal (iron oxide) were spread and the fist-size stones called Enreki (conglomerate) were scattered about.
On the floor of the stone chamber, red powders called Bengal (iron oxide) were spread and the fist-size stones called Enreki (conglomerate) were scattered about.
On the floor of the stone chamber, red powders called Bengal (iron oxide) were spread and the fist-size stones called Enreki (conglomerate) were scattered about.

sen.j: 以前、八角墳は7世紀中頃以降の天皇陵の古墳（天智天皇、天武天皇、持統天皇など）として考えられていた。
sen.e: It is used to be considered that an octagonal burial mound is built as the mausoleum of the Emperor (such as the Emperor Tenchi, the Emperor Tenmu, and the Emperor Jito) constructed after the mid-seventh century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It used to be considered that the octagonal burial mound was built as the mausoleum of the Emperor (such as the Emperor Tenchi, the Emperor Tenmu, and the Emperor Jito) constructed after the mid-seventh century.

It used to be considered that the octagonal burial mound was built as the mausoleum of the Emperor (such as the Emperor Tenchi, the Emperor Tenmu, and the Empress Jito) constructed after the mid-seventh century.
sen.cmt: 持統天皇→女帝のため、Empress Jitoとしました。

sen.j: 東日本では稲荷塚古墳の発見に続き、群馬県藤岡市の伊勢塚古墳、群馬県吉岡町の三津屋古墳、山梨県東八代郡一宮町 (山梨県)（現笛吹市）の経塚古墳と発見が続いたため八角墳に対する考え方を変える事となった。
sen.e: This way of thinking toward an octagonal burial mound was changed, due to the continuous discovery of the Isezuka Kofun (located in Fujioka City, Gunma Prefecture), the Mitsuya Kofun (located in Yoshioka-cho, Gunma Prefecture), and the Kyozuka Kofun (located in Ichinomiya-cho, Higashi Yashiro County, Yamanashi Prefecture [Yamanashi Prefecture][present day Fuefuki City]) after the discovery of the Inarizuka Kofun in the Eastern Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処※原文には () がありませんが、原文の複雑な情報をわかりやすく整理して伝えるため () を用いて訳しました。
sen.e: This way of thinking toward an octagonal burial mound was changed due to the continuous discovery of the Isezuka Kofun (located in Fujioka City, Gunma Prefecture), the Mitsuya Kofun (located in Yoshioka-cho, Gunma Prefecture), and the Kyozuka Kofun (located in Ichinomiya-cho, Higashi Yashiro County, Yamanashi Prefecture [Yamanashi Prefecture][present day Fuefuki City]) after the discovery of the Inarizuka Kofun in the Eastern Japan.

This way of thinking toward an octagonal burial mound was changed due to the continuous discovery of the Isezuka-kofun Tumulus (located in Fujioka City, Gunma Prefecture), the Mitsuya-kofun Tumulus (located in Yoshioka-cho, Gunma Prefecture), and the Kyozuka-kofun Tumulus (located in Ichinomiya-cho, Higashi Yashiro County, Yamanashi Prefecture [present day Fuefuki City]) after the discovery of the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus in the Eastern Japan.
sen.cmt: Kofun→-kofun Tumulusに修正、重複表記のため[Yamanashi Prefecture]削除、余分なスペース消去

sen.j: 全国でおよそ15万基造られた古墳の内、八角墳は全国で15例ほどしかない。
sen.e: Only about fifteen octagonal burial mounds were discovered, although approximately 150,000 burial mounds were constructed in Japan.
Only about fifteen octagonal burial mounds were discovered, although approximately 150,000 burial mounds were constructed in Japan.
Only about fifteen octagonal burial mounds were discovered, although approximately 150,000 burial mounds were constructed in Japan.

sen.j: 6世紀中頃から7世紀中頃（大化の改新）までの多摩を含む関東では大和政権が本州での勢力拡大を行うため、関東以北に勢力のあった毛人（蝦夷）の同化や毛人の強い抵抗による攻防戦、地方豪族による権力争いの調停などを行っていた時代である。
sen.e: In the Kanto region, including the Tama area, the period around from the mid-sixth century to the mid-seventh century (until the Taika Reform) was a time when, in order to expand the sphere of influence in the main land of Japan, the Yamato Regime fought the battles with Moujin ("hairy people "which refers to natives of Ezo), who had an influence in the Kanto region and northward, to conquer them or to prevent their strong resistance and attempted to mediate the power struggles among the regional clans.

In the Kanto region, including the Tama area, the period from the mid-sixth century to the mid-seventh century (until the Taika Reform) was a time when, in order to expand the sphere of influence in the mainland of Japan, the Yamato Regime fought battles with Moujin ("hairy people" which refers to natives of Ezo), who had influence in the Kanto region and northward, to conquer them or to prevent their strong resistance and attempted to mediate the power struggles among the regional clans.

In the Kanto region, including the Tama area, the period from the mid-sixth century to the mid-seventh century (until the Taika Reform) was a time when, in order to expand the sphere of influence in the mainland of Japan, the Yamato Regime fought battles with Mojin ("hairy people" which refers to natives of Ezo), who had influence in the Kanto region and northward, to conquer them or to prevent their strong resistance and attempted to mediate the power struggles among the regional clans.

sen.j: 蘇我蝦夷の「蝦夷」と言う名前はその時代背景から名づけられたとされている。
sen.e: It is said that "Emishi," the last name of Soga no Emishi, was named after the historical background.
It is said that "Emishi," the last name of Soga no Emishi, was named after the historical background.
It is said that "Emishi," the last name of SOGA no Emishi, was named after the historical background.
sen.cmt: Soga no Emishi→SOGA no Emishiに修正

sen.j: 日本書紀には「安閑天皇元年（534年）、武蔵国の国造である笠原直使主の地位を奪うため、南武蔵の小杵は上毛野国の小熊の力を借りて、笠原直使主を殺害しようとした。」
sen.e: According to Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), "in 534, Ogi, who had power over Minamimusashi region, attempted to kill Kasahara no Ataiomi, Kuninomiyatsuko (the local governor) of Musashi Province, with the help of Oguma who governed Kamitsuke Province in order to usurp the position of Kuninomiyatsuko from Kasahara no Ataiomi."

According to Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), "in 534, Ogi, who had power over Minamimusashi region, attempted to kill Kasahara no Ataiomi, Kuninomiyatsuko (the local governor) of Musashi Province, with the help of Oguma who governed Kamitsuke Province in order to usurp the position of Kuninomiyatsuko from Kasahara no Ataiomi."

According to the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), "in 534, Ogi, who had power over Minamimusashi region, attempted to kill Kasahara no Ataiomi, Kuninomiyatsuko (the local governor) of Musashi Province, with the help of Oguma who governed Kamitsuke Province in order to usurp the position of Kuninomiyatsuko from Kasahara no Ataiomi."
sen.cmt: According to the Nihonshokiとしました。

sen.j: 「しかし笠原直使主は大和朝廷と結び小杵を破った(武蔵国造の乱)。」
sen.e: "However, Kasahara no Ataiomi allied with the Yamato Court and defeated Ogi (Musashi-kuninomiyatsuko no ran [Musashi-kuninomiyatsuko Rebellion])."
"However, Kasahara no Ataiomi allied with the Yamato Court and defeated Ogi (Musashi-kuninomiyatsuko no ran [Musashi-kuninomiyatsuko Rebellion])."
"However, Kasahara no Ataiomi allied with the Yamato Court and defeated Ogi (Musashi-kuninomiyatsuko War)."
sen.cmt: 「武蔵国造の乱」→統一事項に基づきMusashi-kuninomiyatsuko Warとしました。

sen.j: 「この結果、笠原直使主は大和朝廷から武蔵国造家であることを認知された。」
sen.e: "As a result, Kasahara no Ataiomi was formally recognized as Musashi Kokusouke (the local governor family) by the Yamato Court."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "As a result, Kasahara no Ataiomi was formally recognized as Musashi Kokusouke (the local governor family) by the Yamato Court."
"As a result, Kasahara no Ataiomi was formally recognized as Musashi Kokusoke (the local governor family) by the Yamato Court."

sen.j: 「その際、笠原直使主は「横渟」、「橘花」、「多氷」、「倉樔」の4ヶ所を屯倉（大和朝廷の直轄地）として献上した。」と記述がある。
sen.e: "At that time, Kasahara no Ataiomi presented four places, "Yokonu," "Tachibana," "Tahi," and "Kurasu," as Miyake (a territory under direct rule from the Yamato Court) to the Yamato Court."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "At that time, Kasahara no Ataiomi presented four places, "Yokonu," "Tachibana," "Tahi," and "Kurasu," as Miyake (a territory under direct rule from the Yamato Court) to the Yamato Court."
"At that time, Kasahara no Ataiomi presented four places, "Yokonu," "Tachibana," "Tahi," and "Kurasu," as Miyake (a territory under direct rule from the Yamato Court) to the Yamato Court."

sen.j: 「多氷（たひ）」は現在の東京都多摩地区とされている。
sen.e: It is thought that "Tahi" is present day Tama area in Tokyo Prefecture.
It is thought that "Tahi" is present day Tama area in Tokyo Prefecture.
It is thought that "Tahi" is present day Tama area in Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 横渟（よこぬ）：埼玉県比企郡吉見町
sen.e: Yokonu: Yoshimi-cho, Hiki County, Saitama Prefecture
Yokonu: Yoshimi-cho, Hiki County, Saitama Prefecture
Yokonu: Yoshimi-cho, Hiki County, Saitama Prefecture

sen.j: 橘花（たちばな）：神奈川県川崎市・横浜市東北部
sen.e: Tachibana: Kawasaki City and the northern part of Yokohama City in Kanagawa Prefecture
Tachibana: Kawasaki City and the northern part of Yokohama City in Kanagawa Prefecture
Tachibana: Kawasaki City and the northern part of Yokohama City in Kanagawa Prefecture

sen.j: 多氷（たひ）：東京都多摩地区
sen.e: Tahi: Tama Area, Tokyo Prefecture
Tahi: Tama Area, Tokyo Prefecture
Tahi: Tama Area, Tokyo Prefecture

sen.j: 倉樔（くらす）：神奈川県横浜市南部
sen.e: Kurasu: The southern part of Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture
Kurasu: The southern part of Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture
Kurasu: The southern part of Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture

sen.j: 聖徳太子、蘇我馬子、推古天皇の死後、大和朝廷では権力争いが激化した。
sen.e: After the death of Prince Shotoku, Soga no Umako, and the Emperor Suiko, a power struggle intensified within the Yamato Court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the death of Prince Shotoku, Soga no Umako, and the Emperor Suiko, a power struggle intensified within the Yamato Court.
After the death of Prince Shotoku, SOGA no Umako, and the Empress Suiko, a power struggle intensified within the Yamato Court.
sen.cmt: Soga no Umako→SOGA no Umako、「推古天皇」→女帝のためEmpress Suikoとしました。

sen.j: その後蘇我氏が権力を振るうが、その強引な行動が蘇我氏に対する皇族や諸豪族の反感を高めた。
sen.e: After the struggle, the Soga clan exercised their power; however, due to their aggressive behaviors, the resentment against the Soga clan was increasing among the imperial family and other regional clans.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the struggle, the Soga clan exercised their power; however, due to their aggressive behavior, the resentment against the Soga clan was increasing among the imperial family and other regional clans.

After the struggle, the Soga clan exercised their power; however, due to their aggressive behavior, the resentment against the Soga clan was increasing among the imperial family and other regional clans.

sen.j: 637年には蝦夷が叛乱を起こし朝貢することを断ったため（現在の群馬県辺り）、大和朝廷は上毛野形名をその地に派遣した。
sen.e: In 637, the Emishi revolted against the Yamato Court and refused to pay a tribute, the Yamato Court dispatched Kamitsukeno no Katana to the place (around present-day Gunma Prefecture).
In 637, the Emishi revolted against the Yamato Court and refused to pay tribute, and the Yamato Court dispatched Kamitsukeno no Katana to the place (around present-day Gunma Prefecture).
In 637, the Emishi revolted against the Yamato Court and refused to pay tribute, and the Yamato Court dispatched KAMITSUKENO no Katana to the place (around present-day Gunma Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Kamitsukeno no Katana→KAMITSUKENO no Katanaとしました。

sen.j: しかし蝦夷の攻防が激しかった。
sen.e: However, the Emishi fought back fiercely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the Emishi fought back fiercely.
However, the Emishi fought back fiercely.

sen.j: 大王による大和朝廷の存続を揺るがし兼ねない事態にまで陥ったが、その反乱は辛うじて鎮圧をしている。
sen.e: The Yamato Court faced to a serious situation which could have threatened its existence, but they could barely suppress the rebellion.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Yamato Court faced to a serious situation which could have threatened its existence, but they could barely suppress the rebellion.
The Yamato Court ruled by the Okimi (Great King) faced to a serious situation which could have threatened its existence, but they could barely suppress the rebellion.
sen.cmt: 「大王による」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。(用語集参照)

sen.j: 643年に蘇我入鹿は山背大兄王を含む聖徳太子の血をひく上宮王家を滅亡させた。
sen.e: In 643, Soga no Iruka ruined the Jogu royal family who had blood relationship with Prince Shotoku.
In 643, Soga no Iruka ruined the Jogu royal family who had a blood relationship with Prince Shotoku.
In 643, SOGA no Iruka ruined the Jogu royal family including Prince Yamashiro no Oe who had a blood relationship with Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: 「山背大兄王を含む」→訳漏れのため訳出、Soga no Iruka→SOGA no Irukaに修正

sen.j: その後645年の乙巳の変、646年の大化の改新により蘇我体制に終止符が打たれた。
sen.e: Later, the Soga regime ended when the Isshi Incident was over in 645 and the Taika Reform was initiated in 646.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処※原文の情報のみで訳した場合、英語として伝わりにくいため、言葉を補って訳しました。
sen.e: Later, the Soga regime ended when the Isshi Incident was over in 645 and the Taika Reform was initiated in 646.
Later, the Soga regime ended when the Isshi Incident was over in 645 and the Taika Reform was initiated in 646.

sen.j: それに伴い、蝦夷に対する政策も変わり7世紀中頃の攻防戦線は東北へ移動をしている（蝦夷征伐）。
sen.e: This affected the policy toward the Emishi and the battle line moved to the northeast in the mid-seventh century (the subjugation of Ezo).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This affected the policy toward the Emishi and the battle line moved to the northeast in the mid-seventh century (the subjugation of Ezo).
This affected the policy toward the Emishi and the battle line moved to the northeast in the mid-seventh century (the subjugation of Ezo).

sen.j: 大化の改新では薄葬令が出された。
sen.e: As a law of the Taika Reform, Hakusorei (the Taika funerary law) was legislated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a law of the Taika Reform, Hakusorei (the Taika funerary law) was legislated.
As a law of the Taika Reform, Hakusorei (the Taika funerary law) was legislated.

sen.j: 天皇以外の豪族・庶民は従来の墓の規模を遙かに縮小し、簡素化している。
sen.e: After the law was enacted, the tombs which were made by clans and ordinary people other than the emperor became much smaller and more simplified than the tombs constructed before the law.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the law was enacted, the tombs which were made by clans and ordinary people other than the emperor became much smaller and more simplified than the tombs constructed before the law.
After the law was enacted, the tombs which were made by clans and ordinary people other than the emperor became much smaller and more simplified than the tombs constructed before the law.

sen.j: その事はその地域での大和朝廷の影響力を知る事ができる。
sen.e: This represents how the Yamato Court had an influence on the region.
This represents how the Yamato Court had an influence on the region.
This represents how the Yamato Court had an influence on the region.

sen.j: 他、大化の改新に伴い大和朝廷の直轄地である屯倉は廃止された。
sen.e: With the establishment of the Taika Reform, Miyake which was the territories under direct rule from the Yamato Court was also abolished.
With the establishment of the Taika Reform, Miyake, which was the territories under direct rule from the Yamato Court, was also abolished.
With the establishment of the Taika Reform, Miyake, which was the territories under direct rule from the Yamato Court, was also abolished.

sen.j: 多摩川の南側にあたる大栗川（多摩川支流）両岸には「和田古墳群」と呼ばれる古墳群がある。
sen.e: There are the group of burial mounds called "Wada Kofungun" on both banks of Okuri river (a tributary of Tamagawa river) which runs on the south side of Tamagawa river.
There is a group of burial mounds called "Wada Kofungun" on both banks of Okuri river (a tributary of Tamagawa river) which runs on the south side of Tamagawa river.
There is a group of burial mounds called "Wada Kofungun" on both banks of Okuri-gawa River (a tributary of Tama-gawa River) which runs on the south side of Tama-gawa River.

sen.j: 大栗川の東側には稲荷塚古墳、臼井塚古墳、庚申塚古墳、塚原古墳群がある。
sen.e: On the east side of Okuri river, there are the Inarizuka Kofun, the Usuizuka Kofun, the Koushinzuka Kofun, and the Tsukapara Kofungun.
On the east side of Okuri river, there are the Inarizuka Kofun, the Usuizuka Kofun, the Koushinzuka Kofun, and the Tsukapara Kofungun.
On the east side of Okuri-gawa River, there are the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus, the Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus, the Koshinzuka-kufun Tumulus, and the Tsukappara Kofungun.

sen.j: 大栗川の西側には中和田横穴墓群、日野市万蔵院台古墳群がある。
sen.e: On the west side of Okuri river, there are the Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs) and the Hino City Manzoindai Kofun burial mounds.
On the west side of Okuri river, there are the Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs) and the Hino City Manzoindai Kofun burial mounds.
On the west side of Okuri-gawa River, there are the Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs) and the Hino City Manzoindai Kofungun burial mounds.
sen.cmt: Okuri-gawa Riverとし、Manzoindai Kofun→Manzoindai Kofungunに修正

sen.j: ほとんどが古墳時代後期にあたる6世紀中頃から7世紀中頃を中心に築造された古墳である。
sen.e: Most of them were built in the late Kofun period from the mid-sixth to the mid-seventh century.
Most of them were built in the late Kofun period from the mid-sixth to the mid-seventh century.
Most of them were built in the late Kofun period from the mid-sixth to the mid-seventh century.

sen.j: 古墳以外に古墳時代の住居跡や土器なども多数発見されている。
sen.e: In addition to the burial mounds, many dwellings and earthenwares were found in the remains of the Kofun period.
In addition to the burial mounds, many dwellings and earthenwares were found in the remains of the Kofun period.
In addition to the burial mounds, many dwellings and earthenwares were found in the remains of the Kofun period.

sen.j: 都内でも有数の古墳群のひとつである。
sen.e: This is one of the largest burial mounds in Tokyo prefecture.
This is one of the largest burial mounds in Tokyo prefecture.
This is one of the largest burial mounds in Tokyo.

sen.j: しかし、その古墳のほとんどは墳丘が削平されている。
sen.e: However, many of burial mounds lost the top parts because they were scraped away and leveled.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, many burial mounds lost the top parts because they were scraped away and leveled.
However, many burial mounds lost the top parts because they were scraped away and leveled.

sen.j: 墳丘が確認できる古墳は少数となっている。
sen.e: The burial mounds which retain the original shapes are getting fewer.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The burial mounds which retain the original shapes are getting fewer.
The burial mounds which retain the original shapes are getting fewer.

sen.j: 周辺は未調査の区域も多く今後、古墳の数が増える可能性は高い。
sen.e: Since many surrounding areas remain to be investigated, it is highly possible that the number of burial mounds to be found will increase further in future.
Since many surrounding areas remain to be investigated, it is highly possible that the number of burial mounds to be found will increase further in the future.
Since many surrounding areas remain to be investigated, it is highly possible that the number of burial mounds to be found will increase further in the future.

sen.j: 臼井塚古墳
sen.e: Usuizuka Kofun Burial Mound
Usuizuka Kofun Burial Mound
Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Usuizuka-kofun Tumulusとしました。

sen.j: 稲荷塚古墳から西方100m付近には臼井塚古墳がある。
sen.e: The Usuizuka Kofun lies about 100 meters to the east from Inarizuka Kofun.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Usuizuka Kofun lies about 100 meters to the east from Inarizuka Kofun.
The Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus lies about 100 meters to the west from Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus.
sen.cmt: to the east→to the westに修正、Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus、Inarizuka-kofun Tumulusとしました。

sen.j: 築造時期は稲荷塚古墳と同じ7世紀前半である。
sen.e: The Usuizuka Kofun was constructed in the first half of the 7th century, the same century when the Inarizuka Kofun was built.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Usuizuka Kofun was constructed in the first half of the 7th century, the same century when the Inarizuka Kofun was built.
The Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus was constructed in the first half of the seventh century, the same century when the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus was built.
sen.cmt: Usuizuka-kofun Tumulus、Inarizuka-kofun Tumulusとし、7th→seventhとしました。

sen.j: 凝灰岩の切石を用いた胴張複室構造の石室である。
sen.e: The stone chamber with a structure called the Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (the womb-like structure) was constructed by using the cut tuff stones.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処読み方＆定訳不明→「胴張複室構造」
sen.e: The stone chamber with a structure called the Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo (the womb-like structure) was constructed using cut tuff stones.
The stone chamber with a structure called the Dohari-fukushitsu-kozo was constructed using cut tuff stones.

sen.j: 石室は稲荷塚古墳よりも小さいが、構造は同じである。
sen.e: The size of the stone chamber is smaller than that of the Inarizuka Kofun, but the structures are the same.
The size of the stone chamber is smaller than that of the Inarizuka Kofun, but the structures are the same.
The size of the stone chamber is smaller than that of the Inarizuka-kofun Tumulus, but the structures are the same.

sen.j: 現在、石室は埋め戻されている。
sen.e: The stone chamber is currently backfilled.
The stone chamber is currently backfilled.
The stone chamber is currently backfilled.

sen.j: 庚申塚古墳
sen.e: Koushinzuka Kofun Burial Mound
Koushinzuka Kofun Burial Mound
Koshinzuka-kofun Tumulus
sen.cmt: Koushinzuka→Koshinzukaに修正、表記統一のため、Kofun Burial Mound→-kofun Tumulusとしました。

sen.j: 現在未調査であるが、直径10mの円墳と推測される。
sen.e: Although the burial mound has not yet been investigated, it is estimated that it is a round burial mound with a diameter of 10 meters.
Although the burial mound has not yet been investigated, it is estimated that it is a round burial mound with a diameter of 10 meters.
Although the Koshinzuka-kofun Tumulus has not yet been investigated, it is estimated that it is a round burial mound with a diameter of 10 meters.
sen.cmt: the burial mound→the Koshinzuka-kofun Tumulusとしました。

sen.j: 石室の一部と思われる河原石が露出している。
sen.e: Some river stones which seem to be a part of the stone chamber are exposed.
Some river stones which seem to be a part of the stone chamber are exposed.
Some river stones which seem to be a part of the stone chamber are exposed.

sen.j: 現在墳頂部に庚申塔が祀られている。
sen.e: On the top of the burial mound, Koushinto (Koshin tower) is enshrined.
On the top of the burial mound, Koushinto (Koshin tower) is enshrined.
On the top of the burial mound, Koshinto (Koshin tower) is enshrined.

sen.j: 塚原古墳群（つかっぱらこふんぐん）
sen.e: Tsukapara Kofungun Burial Mounds
Tsukapara Kofungun Burial Mounds
Tsukappara Kofungun Burial Mounds

sen.j: 6世紀中頃から7世紀中頃までの100年間に渡り造られた古墳群である。
sen.e: The Tsukapara Kofungun are the group of burial mounds constructed during the 100 years between the mid-sixth century and the mid-seventh century.
The Tsukapara Kofungun are a group of burial mounds constructed during the 100 years between the mid-sixth century and the mid-seventh century.
The Tsukappara Kofungun are a group of burial mounds constructed during the 100 years between the mid-sixth century and the mid-seventh century.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の新編武蔵風土記稿には「古墳が元禄の頃には40～50基あったが、14、5基に減少した。」とされている。
sen.e: According to Shinpen Musashi Fudo Kiko (a topography of Musashi Province from 1804 to 1829) written in the late Edo period, "Although there were 40 - 50 burial mounds in the Genroku period, the number fell to 14 or 15."

According to Shinpen Musashi Fudo Kiko (a topography of Musashi Province from 1804 to 1829) written in the late Edo period, "Although there were 40 - 50 burial mounds in the Genroku period, the number fell to 14 or 15."

According to the Shinpen Musashi Fudo Kiko (a topography of Musashi Province from 1804 to 1829) written in the late Edo period, "Although there were 40 - 50 burial mounds in the Genroku era, the number fell to 14 or 15."
sen.cmt: According to the Shinpen Musashi Fudo Kikoとし、the Genroku period→the Genroku eraに修正

sen.j: しかし現在までに確認されているのは10基である。
sen.e: However, only 10 burial mounds have been found until now.
However, only 10 burial mounds have been found so far.
However, only 10 burial mounds have been found so far.

sen.j: 川原石を用いた横穴式石室を持つ円墳の古墳群であり、副葬品が多数発見されている。
sen.e: They are round burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu created using the river stones, from which many burial items were discovered.
They are round burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu created using river stones, from which many burial items were discovered.
They are round burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu created using river stones, from which many burial items were discovered.

sen.j: 中和田横穴墓群
sen.e: Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs)
Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs)
Nakawada Oketsubogun (Nakawada tunnel tombs)

sen.j: 多摩丘陵最大の横穴墓群で19基の横穴墓が発見されている。
sen.e: They are the largest tunnel tombs found in Tama Hillside and 19 tunnel tombs were found there.
They are the largest tunnel tombs found in Tama Hillside, and 19 tunnel tombs were found there.
They are the largest tunnel tombs found in Tama Hillside, and 19 tunnel tombs were found there.

sen.j: それぞれ、方形単室形、胴張り複室形、台形単室形の横穴墓である。
sen.e: The structures of the tunnel tombs are Houkei-tanshitsukei (rectangular single room), Dohari-fukushitsukei (multiple rooms with the womb-like structure), and Daikei-tanshitsukei (trapezoidal single room).
sen.cmt: 読み方＆定訳不明→「方形単室形、胴張り複室形、台形単室形」
sen.e: The structures of the tunnel tombs are Houkei-tanshitsukei (rectangular single room), Dohari-fukushitsukei (multiple rooms with the womb-like structure), and Daikei-tanshitsukei (trapezoidal single room).

The structures of the tunnel tombs are Hokei-tanshitsukei (rectangular single room), Dohari-fukushitsukei (multiple rooms with the womb-like structure), and Daikei-tanshitsukei (trapezoidal single room).

sen.j: 10体分ほどの人骨も発見されている。
sen.e: About 10 human bones were also found.
About 10 human bones were also found.
The bones of about 10 people were also found.
sen.cmt: 「10体分ほどの人骨」を修正しました。

sen.j: 7世紀前半から8世紀初頭までの横穴墓と推測される。
sen.e: It is estimated that the tunnel tombs were built around from the first half of the seventh century to the early eighth century.
It is estimated that the tunnel tombs were built around the first half of the seventh century to the early eighth century.
It is estimated that the tunnel tombs were built around the first half of the seventh century to the early eighth century.

sen.j: 副葬品として太刀、鉄鏃、刀子、ガラス玉、土師器杯、須恵器横瓶などがある。
sen.e: The burial items, such as swords, iron arrowheads, small size swords, glass beads, Hajiki-hai (Haji pottery for sake cup), and Sueki-yokobin (oblong earthen bottles), were discovered.
The burial items, such as swords, iron arrowheads, small swords, glass beads, Hajiki-hai (Haji pottery for sake cup), and Sueki-yokobin (oblong earthen bottles) were discovered.
The burial items, such as swords, iron arrowheads, small swords, glass beads, Hajiki-hai (Haji pottery for sake cup), and Sueki-yokobin (oblong earthen bottles) were discovered.

sen.j: 日野市万蔵院台古墳群
sen.e: Hino City Manzoindai Kofungun Burial Mounds
Hino City Manzoindai Kofungun Burial Mounds
Hino City Manzoindai Kofungun Burial Mounds

sen.j: 河原石を用いた横穴式石室で3基の古墳が確認されている。
sen.e: They are burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu constructed using the river stones and three burial mounds have been found.
They are burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu constructed using river stones, and three burial mounds have been found.
They are burial mounds with Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu constructed using river stones, and three burial mounds have been found.

sen.j: 1号墳は胴張り単室、2号墳は片袖式単室、3号墳は無袖式長方形単室である。
sen.e: The first tomb has a room with Dohari-tanshitsu structure (single room with a womb-like structure), the second tomb has a room with Katasodesiki-tanshitsu structure, and the third tomb has a room with the Musodesiki-chohokei-tanshitsu structure.
sen.cmt: 読み方＆定訳不明→「胴張り単室」、「片袖式単室」、「無袖式長方形単室」
sen.e: The first tomb has a room with Dohari-tanshitsu structure (single room with a womb-like structure), the second tomb has a room with Katasodesiki-tanshitsu structure, and the third tomb has a room with the Musodesiki-chohokei-tanshitsu structure.

The first tomb has a room with Dohari-tanshitsu structure (single room with a womb-like structure), the second tomb has a room with Katasodesiki-tanshitsu structure, and the third tomb has a room with the Musodesiki-chohokei-tanshitsu structure.

sen.j: 築造時期は6世紀第4四半期(575-600)と推測されている。
sen.e: It is estimated that they were constructed around the fourth quarter of the sixth century (575 - 600).
It is estimated that they were constructed around the fourth quarter of the sixth century (575 - 600).
It is estimated that they were constructed around the fourth quarter of the sixth century (575 - 600).

sen.j: 塚原古墳群と築造時期や石室の構造などが似通っている。
sen.e: The age of construction and the structure of the stone chamber have similarities to the Tsukapara Kofungun.
The age of construction and the structure of the stone chamber have similarities to the Tsukapara Kofungun.
The age of construction and the structure of the stone chamber have similarities to the Tsukappara Kofungun.

sen.j: 所在地：東京都多摩市百草1140
sen.e: Address: 1140 Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture
Address: 1140 Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture
Address: 1140 Mogusa, Tama City, Tokyo Prefecture

sen.j: 被葬者：不明
sen.e: The occupant of the tomb: Unknown
The occupant of the tomb: Unknown
The occupant of the tomb: Unknown

sen.j: 築造時期：古墳時代後期(7世紀前半)
sen.e: The age of construction: The late Kofun period (the first half of the seventh century).
The age of construction: The late Kofun period (the first half of the seventh century).
The age of construction: The late Kofun period (the first half of the seventh century)

sen.j: 墳 形：八角墳
sen.e: Shape: An octagonal burial mound.
Shape: An octagonal burial mound.
Shape: An octagonal burial mound

sen.j: 規 模：全長約38m・高さ約4m(現在約半分)、周溝幅約2m
sen.e: Size: About 38 meters in total length, about 4 meters in height (the current height is about half of the length), and the surrounding ditch of about 2 meters width.
Size: About 38 meters in total length, about 4 meters in height (the current height is about half of the length), and the surrounding ditch of about 2 meters in width.
Size: About 38 meters in total length, about 4 meters in height (the current height is about half of the length), and the surrounding ditch of about 2 meters in width

sen.j: 埋葬部：2段目に切石造りの羨道部・前室・玄室を持つ凝灰岩の複室横穴式石室(全長約7.7m)
sen.e: Interior: The interior has the Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu, which was constructed of the cut tuff stones, with the Sendo-bu passageway and the zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms, all which are located on the second tier.

Interior: The interior has the Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu, which was constructed of cut tuff stones, with the Sendo-bu passageway and the zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms, all which are located on the second tier.

Interior: The interior has the Yokoana-shiki sekishitsu, which was constructed of cut tuff stones, with the Sendo-bu passageway and the zenshitsu and genshitsu rooms, all which are located on the second tier.

sen.j: 出土遺物：不明(明治初年の盗掘のため）
sen.e: Burial Items: Unknown (due to grave robbing in the early years of Meiji period.)
Burial Items: Unknown (due to grave robbing in the early years of the Meiji period.)
Burial Items: Unknown (due to grave robbing in the early years of the Meiji period)

sen.j: 交 通：京王線聖蹟桜ヶ丘駅よりバス「落川」下車徒歩７分
sen.e: Transportation: Seven minutes walk from the bus stop, "Ochikawa."
Transportation: Seven minutes walk from the bus stop, "Ochikawa."
Transportation: Take a bus from the Keio Line Seiseki-sakuragaoka Station, get off at the bus stop "Ochikawa" and walk seven minutes.
